JUDGES: Alvina Gyulumyan;Corneliu Bîrsan;Egbert Myjer;Ján Šikuta;Josep Casadevall;Kristina Pardalos;Luis López Guerra;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE .
CARDINAL . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) are represented by their Agent , PERSON , of ORG .
CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . NORP In a final decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG convicted the applicant of murder and sentenced him to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment .

CARDINAL . The applicant lodged several requests for revision of the final decision . They were all rejected by the courts on the grounds that the applicant had failed to bring evidence that would warrant the reopening of the proceedings and that no new facts or circumstances had been discovered that would have been unknown at the date when the final decision had been taken .
CARDINAL . CARDINAL of those requests were dismissed by different panels of ORG on CARDINAL and DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant started serving his prison sentence on DATE . He remained in prison until DATE when he was released conditionally . During his term of imprisonment , he was transferred CARDINAL times between CARDINAL prisons and CARDINAL prison hospitals , as required by his state of health or a number of on - going court cases in which he was involved .

CARDINAL . At the beginning of the detention period , it had been recorded that the applicant was suffering from lumbar lordosis ( discopatie lombară ) and psychopathy , the latter having been first diagnosed in DATE . The prison medical records indicate that he had received medical care and treatment for his condition .
CARDINAL . During his detention , he was also diagnosed with heart disease , sick sinus syndrome and peripheral vascular disease .
CARDINAL . On several occasions he was admitted to prison hospitals for treatment of heart disease and mental illness . He was also prescribed a special diet .

CARDINAL . The applicant was held in ORG on several occasions from DATE to CARDINAL DATE and returned there on a number of occasions later in his sentence . He claimed that despite his mental illness he had had to work TIME a day in DATE and DATE . During that time , because of overcrowding , CARDINAL detainees had been sharing one bed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant brought an action against CARDINAL members of the commission that had given him permission to work , seeking damages under Articles CARDINAL of the former Civil Code . On CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed his action on the grounds that he had failed to prove a causal link between the CARDINAL defendants and the alleged damage . On DATE that decision was upheld on its merits by ORG . The applicant ’s subsequent appeal in cassation was declared null and void by ORG in a final decision of DATE , as the applicant had failed to submit the reasons for his appeal within the time - limit .

CARDINAL . According to information provided by ORG ( PERSON ) , the applicant was held in FAC CARDINAL times during his sentence , his detention there ranging from DATE to DATE at a time . After DATE smoking was prohibited in all cells and there were designated areas for smoking .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL occasions while detained in FAC , in DATE and DATE , the applicant voluntarily took an overdose of medication . After detoxification , the doctors recommended psychiatric assistance at FAC . After each episode , the applicant was transferred DATE for DATE the first time and DATE the second time DATE to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG dismissed as ill - founded an action brought by the applicant against the prison governor and doctor concerning the conditions of his detention in FAC . He complained that he was being held with dangerous detainees and that he had not received adequate treatment for his psychiatric condition . He also complained that the governor had not assisted him in obtaining his pension file from GPE ( a procedure described under point CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . The court noted that the applicant ’s placement in one cell or another had been determined by the prison ’s internal regulations and had not been left to the discretion of the governor . It also noted that while the applicant ’s mental illness entitled him to special detention conditions , it did not entitle him to privileges . Concerning the allegations of lack of medical treatment , the court noted that the applicant had received medication , and considered that the prison doctor was not responsible for the fact that the applicant had taken an overdose by swallowing all the pills at once .

CARDINAL . The court also noted that the fact that the applicant did not enjoy the food he received was not imputable to either the governor or the doctor , in so far as the applicant could not prove that he had suffered any injurious consequences from his diet .

CARDINAL . Lastly , the court noted that the applicant had applied to ORG for an expert evaluation in order to have his pension rights established , and therefore concluded that neither the governor nor the doctor had committed any illegal acts that would render them responsible in this regard ( nu există faptă ilicită ) .

CARDINAL . The official prison records indicate that DATE the applicant received QUANTITY envelopes with stamps for his correspondence . CARDINAL other similar requests were refused by the prison administration , either on the basis that the applicant had recently received a large number of envelopes or because he had had sufficient funds in his account to allow him to purchase the envelopes himself . He did not complain about those decisions .
CARDINAL . On DATE , CARDINAL and DATE and CARDINAL DATE the applicant asked for permission to visit his sick mother , but his requests were dismissed by the prison board in charge .

CARDINAL . It appears that the applicant did not lodge an appeal against the prison authorities’ decision with the courts under Ordinance no . CARDINAL or PERSON no . LANGUAGE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE , while in detention in FAC , the applicant applied to ORG for temporary release from prison on the grounds that his family needed his help with farming . He argued before the court that he would return to prison given that if he were released , he could not afford the medical care he had received free of charge in prison .
The court dismissed his application on DATE . The applicant did not appeal against the decision .
CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicant informed the ORG that he had problems with his dentition and alleged that the dental care he had received in prison was insufficient .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant received dental care in FAC in DATE and DATE . He had one tooth removed and another treated .

CARDINAL . On DATE a medical commission from PERSON ( consisting of a dentist and an accountant ) noted that the applicant had missing teeth and proposed a dental prosthesis plan , while nevertheless noting that “ his dental problems were not significant ” . The dentition model in the medical report shows that the applicant was missing CARDINAL left and CARDINAL right molars . The commission estimated the total cost of treatment at CARDINAL NORP lei ( PERSON ) , of which CARDINAL ORG were payable by the applicant . Their estimate was based on Order No . CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE issued by the Minister of ORG together with the President of ORG ( PERSON a ORG ) .
CARDINAL . The commission noted , however , that the applicant had no money available in his account and that PERSON lacked the facilities necessary to treat the applicant .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant lodged a complaint before the NORP ORG against ORG and others , the heirs of ORG , seeking damages of CARDINAL old NORP lei ( ROL ) , representing the value of goods and cattle that he claimed he had lent to GPE
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the action as time - barred . That decision was upheld by ORG .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant lodged another complaint against the heirs of GPE , seeking to compel them to pay interest on an alleged loan of CARDINAL ORG that he had made to ORG His action was dismissed in a final decision of DATE by ORG on the grounds that the applicant had not proved that the initial loan was ever made .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an action against the GPE local authorities , seeking restitution of CARDINAL calves and a CARDINAL pig , which had allegedly been confiscated from him by the communist authorities in DATE . He claimed that in DATE the local authorities had informed him that they had returned the animals to GPE

CARDINAL . On DATE the NORP ORG found that the applicant had failed to adduce any proof of his allegations and dismissed the action . By a final decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG declared his appeal null and void as he had not paid the relevant court fees .
CARDINAL . In a decision of CARDINAL DATE the authorities declared the applicant unfit for work due to a pre - existing condition that had worsened during his military service .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date during his detention the applicant requested that an invalidity pension be paid to him .

CARDINAL . At the request of ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) on DATE the applicant underwent an expert evaluation by ORG to determine his capacity for work ( ORG expertiză medicală şi recuperare a capacităţii de muncă ) . The evaluation report confirmed the applicant ’s invalidity and set CARDINAL DATE as the date for review of his situation .

CARDINAL . ORG asked ORG assessment ( ORG FAC – “ the ORG ” ) to express its opinion on the expert report issued in DATE . ORG confirmed the previous assessment , but added that the DATE decision did not entitle the applicant to an invalidity pension . It therefore suggested that ORG evaluate the applicant ’s situation in the light of LAW ( Law No . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided not to grant the applicant an invalidity pension , as he did not meet the requirements set forth in LAW . The decision was upheld by ORG on DATE and by ORG in a final decision of DATE .

CARDINAL . The domestic legislation on the execution of sentences , in particular PERSON no . TIME , Emergency Ordinance no . CARDINAL on the rights of prisoners ( Ordinance no . CARDINAL ) , and PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on the execution of sentences ( PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) are described in LOC v. GPE ( no . MONEY , § § DATE , DATE ) . The situation as regards dental care in the NORP prison system is described in GPE v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE ) .
